results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film contains some of the Hayes family favourites – their assorted pets including the star of many of the films, Ticka the cockatoo, their farm animals and views of the areas surrounding their home in Heathmont. There is also a brief visit to the beach.

A feature of the film is some early views of Ringwood shops and traffic including good examples of cars of the day and the very new looking ‘Holden Bill Paterson Motors’. Bill Paterson was a successful racing car driver of his era. We also see advertising signs of the day such as ‘Whelan the Wrecker’ and ‘Dickies’ and a vintage ‘red rattler’ train crossing the Yarra so likely to be the Port Melbourne/St Kilda line now a lightrail.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is a composite film of Hayes family life across the generations to include the grandchildren. The first segment is titled, ‘The Animals’ and features the family pets including dogs, calves, cows and the audacious cockatoo named Ticka, at home in suburban Heathmont in Melbourne’s outer east.

There are travel scenes of Narracan East, King River and the ‘Astor’ motel at Albury where Charles takes some dramatic footage of the Hume Weir. The family were keen tennis players and visited Albury at Easter so likely took part in the Albury Tennis Association competitions.

As well are some beach scenes at Point Leo, Golden Beach and Frankston where we see one of the dogs up to its neck in sand and some great examples of sixties bathing suits and sun hats.

The filmmaker shows some of the great cars at the time so that we see examples of 1960s and 1970s models. A brief segment from the Moomba Festival in Melbourne shows the ‘Frankston by the Sea’ song lyrics on one of the floats at the time.

Charles also shows the family’s involvement in tennis, trying out an early model Cortina car, and celebrating ‘Elinor’s 21st’ in white gloves and evening gowns and a display of the presents.

A particular feature of the film is the footage of ‘Southgate Fountain’ public art work by Robin Boyd (now demolished to make way for the redevelopment of Southgate on Melbourne’s Yarra river).

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:34:00 calves up close
00:00:53:00 a calf and a dog nuzzling and playing
00:01:33:00 family pet dog and ‘Ticka’ the cockatoo
00:02:49:00 a shivering new born calf taking first wobbly steps
00:03:19:00 Olwyn Hayes and pet dog in close-up
00:04:29:00 Ticka the pet cockatoo on a perch in the backyard
00:05:19:00 Ticka the pet cockatoo eating with family members at the kitchen table
00:05:50:00 decorated cakes for birthday and Christmas.
00:06:24:00 Olwyn and Elenor in matching dresses, likely to be home made
00:06:57:00 title card ‘Narracan East’.
00:07:32:00 family group posing for the camera on a farm tractor
00:08:18:00 Narracan Falls on the Narracan Creek in Gippsland
00:09:15:00 a scene featuring a Cortina car in the family driveway
00:10:10:00 small boy, likely to be one of the filmmakers grandsons, kicking a large coloured ball in the backyard
00:10:40:00 title card ‘King River’
00:11:02:00 younger family members toasting bread on an open fire
00:11:13:00 caravan and Falcon station wagon
00:13:19:00 younger family members putting out the hay for cattle at the family farm
00:13:33:00 younger family members enjoying a ride around the farm yard in a vintage car
00:14:46:00 a family tennis group posing together for the camera
00:15:47:00 ‘Pennant Winners 1963’ title card
00:16:39:00 ‘Pennant Winners 1964’ title card
00:18:58:00 ‘Albury Easter 1964’ title card
00:19:32:00 a Holden car parked at the weir
00:19:58:00 ‘Astor’ Motel/Hotel
00:20:25:00 a look at inside the Astor Motel room
00:20:38:00 swimming and boating on the weir
00:24:56:00 Elenor’s 21st birthday cake
00:24:02:00 the girls of the family in a pillowfight wearing ‘shorty’ or ‘babydoll’ pyjamas (a style of night wear popular at the time and often handmade at home)
00:24:45:00 picnic table set for afternoon tea in shady trees
00:25:06:00 Elenor’s 21st birthday presents on display including her modelling a sleeping bag
00:25:30:00 Olwyn and Elenor modelling their formal gowns with the Dandenong Ranges in the background
00:26:59:00 ‘Point Leo’ title card
00:27:54:00 family dog buried up to his neck in the sand
00:29:49:00 ‘golden Beach’ title card
00:30:00:00 Ansett-ANA helicopter
00:30:15:00 roadside picnic
00:30:41:00 ‘Testing Camera Zoomex’ title card
00:32:42:00 surfing on longboards
00:33:33:00 view across the Yarra River in Melbourne toward the now demolished (to make way for Federation Square) Gas & Fuel buildings in Flinders St
00:34:14:00 ‘Southgate Fountain’ public art work by Robin Boyd now demolished (to make way for the redevelopment of Southgate on Melbourne’s Yarra river)

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movie Collection]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Papua New Guinea, United Kingdom and United States, 1960-1979
results.material_description: 9 x large & 5 x small Super-8mm reels of home movie footage, labelled O/S & Pacific Island cruises, New Guinea, Ireland, "Messiah" etc
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.
results.headline_credit_for_label: Australia, Papua New Guinea, United Kingdom and United States, 1960-1979

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

Short film of wedding reception of David Rowe. Relates to B2003514. Also features the Lae War cemetery, which features on B2003516.

Selected Highlights List from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens at Lae War Cemetary
00:00:45:00 local New Guinea football/rugby team play a match
00:01:23:00 wedding ceremony outdoors

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This is a very short film, featuring graduating students posing with certificates from Goroka Technical College, Margot Gillian, Chapel and opening of the Development Bank at Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:01:07:00 opening of Development Bank, Goroka
00:01:43:00 local group perform ceremony in traditional dress to celebrate opening of bank
00:02:11:00 amazing mouth pieces worn by First Peoples as part of their ceremonial dress, procession

results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This very short film contains footage of mountains on the way to Lae, New Guinea. It relates to reel B2003518.

results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This very short film features a Goroka Technical College students’ graduation ceremony (renamed University of Goroka, possibly Goroka Teachers College). Many students in western graduation robes, some in traditional dress.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:01:20:00 two elders play wind pipes in honour or to welcome students

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film captures a wedding in Goroka, featuring Evelyn Sinclair and friends. The happy couple take off in an airplane for their honeymoon. Relates to reel B2003518.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan) 00:00:00:00 guests at wedding
00:00:25:00 wedding car decorated
00:00:28:00 happy couple cutting the wedding cake
00:01:01:00 bride and groom posing in front of plane; ‘Just Hitched’ sprayed onto the front of the plane
00:01:25:00 happy couple takes off in airplane

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1974
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This films shows time with First Nations people of New Guinea, a wedding in Goroka, a wedding in Sydney, and a royal visit of Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip and Princess Anne to Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:19:00 ancestral house of worship – “House of Tambaran” – seems to be specific to East Sepik group in PNG
00:00:36:00 children in traditional local dress with elders, gathered and building houses
00:01:07:00 playing wooden instruments, similar to flute and pipes
00:01:30:00 stunning views of mountain scene
00:02:20:00 driving through Australian bush, then Sydney beaches
00:07:48:00 toddler in wading pool in yard, Goroka
00:10:04:00 wedding in Goroka
00:12:24:00 carnival or fair, possibly the Sydney Royal Easter Show
00:13:17:00 footage of Sydney Opera House, Circular Quay and a ferry cruise on the Sydney Harbour
00:14:55:00 views of Bondi or Bronte
00:15:38:00 friends gather in Sydney for a wedding
00:16:31:00 back to PNG, family and friends
00:17:42:00 gathering in town in traditional dress to welcome Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip and Princess Anne
00:19:49:00 Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Princess Anne, Captain Phillip, Barry Holloway MP in back of truck being driven through crowds of people, Goroka

description_for_label:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This films shows time with First Nations people of New Guinea, a wedding in Goroka, a wedding in Sydney, and a royal visit of Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip and Princess Anne to Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:19:00 ancestral house of worship – “House of Tambaran” – seems to be specific to East Sepik group in PNG
00:00:36:00 children in traditional local dress with elders, gathered and building houses
00:01:07:00 playing wooden instruments, similar to flute and pipes
00:01:30:00 stunning views of mountain scene
00:02:20:00 driving through Australian bush, then Sydney beaches
00:07:48:00 toddler in wading pool in yard, Goroka
00:10:04:00 wedding in Goroka
00:12:24:00 carnival or fair, possibly the Sydney Royal Easter Show
00:13:17:00 footage of Sydney Opera House, Circular Quay and a ferry cruise on the Sydney Harbour
00:14:55:00 views of Bondi or Bronte
00:15:38:00 friends gather in Sydney for a wedding
00:16:31:00 back to PNG, family and friends
00:17:42:00 gathering in town in traditional dress to welcome Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip and Princess Anne
00:19:49:00 Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Princess Anne, Captain Phillip, Barry Holloway MP in back of truck being driven through crowds of people, Goroka

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Fiji, New Caledonia and New Zealand, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film shows a cruise from Sydney Harbour to possibly New Caledonia, Fiji and New Zealand, including scenic views, time with friends’ son and off the cruise ship.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:34:00 leaving Sydney Harbour in cruise ship; views of the Opera House and the Harbour
00:01:36:00 views from lookout wth friends, looking over a small city
00:04:27:00 a day trip from cruise to island, maybe New Caledonia, due to circular style of grass hut
00:05:26:00 ring volleyball game on cruise ship
00:06:43:00 views from cruise ship coming into port at Nadi, Fiji
00:08:26:00 filmmaker’s wife Evelyn with local family, and swimming at the beach
00:10:08:00 cruise ship coming into port, marching band farewells/welcomes passengers
00:11:50:00 Rainbow Springs sign, Rotorua, NZ
00:12:06:00 trout farm at Rainbow Springs Nature Park
00:13:42:00 hot springs in New Zealand
0014:27:00 cruise ship coming back into Sydney harbour, views of cliffs surrounding Sydney Harbour
results.headline_credit_for_label: Australia, Fiji, New Caledonia and New Zealand, c. 1970s
